local_narrative:
Mobile Bay is a gem of our state. It is rich with life, and once had even more riches. Our coastal communities were founded upon a reliance on our waters, and these waters are a part of the fabric of our economies and cultures.

The commercial oyster and fishing communities have come out strongly in defiance of federal mud dumping. Their message has remained consistent and strong throughout the entirety of the campaign. 

Recreational sportsmen have also decried the practice. The aerial footage of dredging operations near Middle Bay Light galvanized the movement. 

Most of the local citizens engaged with the issue want an end to in-Bay disposal. They understand that its a historical abberation and that funds can be made available for offshore disposal.
messaging_watchouts: There is a potential that some electeds may call for more time … more time for studies, more time for legislative negotiation. These calls for further negotiation may even come from electeds who’d previously espoused support for a ban on mud dumping.
risk_and_minefields:
With the shutdown happening on October 1, it looks the effort to get funds appropriated for the offshore disposal of dredge funds is dead in the water. 

Now the effort turns to WRDA, and putting pressure on legislators to get the language enacted in the 2026 bill. The timeline on this could vary. 

There is the risk of Sens. Britt and Tuberville withdrawing support, or having support wane, for WRDA, especially in light of Congressional dysfunction. 

Another risk is the prospect of losing the momentum of community engagement as the WRDA process drags on.
